I'm having trouble trying to reproduce this one.
Do you have a sample file you can attach w/ steps to recreate?

To me seems unlikely that the NPE is causing the hang, but may be a side
effect of something else that is wrong.  Somewhere to start looking might be the
IllegalArgumentException from the ExtensibleURIResolver...

Also a thread dump might be useful if you get to the "hung" state again.
You can invoke this by hitting "ctrl + break" in the console
(if you are running eclipse w/ the "-consolelog" argument)

Thanks for your input.
changing resolution to REMIND as we are awaiting more info.

This bug kind-of still exists: the NPE no longer occurs and Eclipse doesn't race like it used to, but the other part of the problematic behavior still exists.  I think that this repro is still within the original intent of the bug even though this doesn't match the original summary.


Repro:
File -> New -> Project... -> Web -> Dynamic Web Project
Project Name: SimpleWeb

SimpleWeb/WebContent -> New -> Other... -> Web -> JSP
File Name: index.jsp

Open index.jsp
Add the following right after the page directives:
<%@taglib uri="http://beehive.apache.org/netui/tags-template-1.0" prefix="netui-template"%>
Highlight netui-template and change to c
Highlight the uri attribute contents and type http://


Expected Results:
http://

Actual Results:
http//:


In the past, any letters still typed (i.e. if I typed http://java.sun), then I would see http//: and then my processor usage would go way up and each additional letter would take many seconds to appear; I would also see the original NPE in my .log.

Agreed.  The TLDCMDocumentManager is trying to resolve a "uri" value and instead of getting a result or null, is getting an java.lang.IllegalArgumentException thrown in its face.  I think the ExtensibleURIResolver should be handling these kinds of exceptions for us since its use of the URI class is completely internal.

There's a couple of problems here. One we'll count as a dup of bug 108325, which I re-opened and will submit fix for RC1, for 11/30. 

The second is that validateURI (or parseURI) needs to be "beefed up" to handle 
a URI that ends in only ':'.
